sub_title: Researcher and Lecturer at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU Amsterdam)
summary:
Dr. Nina Schroeder is an art historian specialized in seventeenth-century Dutch art and early modern religious history. Originally from Canada, she is currently a postdoctoral researcher with the Dutch Mennonite Seminary and the Faculty of Religion and Theology at the Vrije Universiteit in Amsterdam. She is coordinator of the University's undergraduate minor, Peace Theology and Anabaptist-Mennonite Traditions, and she conducts research on Dutch Mennonite life and artistic engagement in the early modern period. In her doctoral research with the art history department at Queen's University, she investigated the representations of early Anabaptism in Dutch art (Heretics and Martyrs: Picturing Early Anabaptism in Visual Culture of the Dutch Republic). Her research interests include Dutch Golden Age painting, early modern print history, reception history of early Anabaptism, and Mennonite social networks within the Dutch art marketplace.  She also works on the history of early modern religious dissent movements and explores points of connection between art history and the networks of early modern religious nonconformists, including heterodox early Enlightenment thinkers. 

Nina has experience with lecturing in the university context, and she also has museum experience in the areas of curatorial research, art exhibition development, collections management, historical interpretation, and educational programming at a variety of institutions (the Winnipeg Art Gallery; the Agnes Etherington Art Centre, Kingston; Lower Fort Garry National Historic Site; and, most recently, the Rembrandt House Museum, the RKD, and the Museum Our Lord in the Attic in the Netherlands). She is comfortable working in English (native language), French (advanced), and Dutch (advanced).  Nina is currently working on her SSRHC-funded research project, "Mennonites and Art in the Dutch Republic: Church, Home, and Art Marketplace."
